data.title: Auto indent doesn't work with code blocks JavaScript
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:18:47.188Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: none
---
Language: Javascript:

When creating first code block "{" and pressing enter the auto fill and indent doesn't quite work as it used to, it creates the closing block and creates new lines, but does not indent them back to where they should be

a for loop looks like:
```
for(var key in object)
    {

    }
```

instead of:
```
for(var key in object)
{

}
```

the other way of doing it works fine when it looks like:
```
for(var key in object){

}
```

The same happens with if statements too, but it doesn't happen with switch statements
Steps to Reproduce:

1. create one side of code block "{" 
2. press enter to auto fill the rest

data.title: Untitled workspace is always remembered even when hot-exit is off
data.body:
Testing #30722:

- disable hot-exit
- Create an untitled workspace with two folders
- close workbench window

Observe: you are not asked whether you want to save the workspace but when restarting VS Code the untitled workspace is opened automatically

data.title: Clicking object method triggers to change the active file in explorer window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04
- Project code example for following use case: asp.net core application

In visual studio code when you click on a method of an object, to view the code of that method, the explorer (project) window will change the active file (where you did the click on the method) to the file of the method you clicked.

Is there a way to disable this behavior: so to open the file of the method but keep the explorer window on the file that you were working in? If this is not possible, could you create an option to change this behaviour?

See also stackoverflow question: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45082909/clicking-object-method-triggers-to-change-the-active-file-in-explorer-window

data.title: *.code-workspace files are always auto-saved
data.body:
Testing #30722:

- Turn of auto-save and hot-exit
- add or remove folders from workspace and notice the modification time of the corresponding *.code-workspace file

Observe: the file is immediately updated on disk

data.title: New Workspace should be seeded with the original folder
data.body:
Testing #30722

I have two folders carbon-core and carbon-extension and I want to create a workspace that contains these folders.

- open the folder carbon-core
- select 'Add Folder to Workspace'
- the info box shows up
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/172399/28363555-466991c4-6c81-11e7-9060-b4972960d84b.png)
- I confirm that I want to create a workspace and select 'New Workspace'
- A folder dialog shows up and I select carbon-extension, the folder I wanted to add to the workspace
- A new workspace opens with the status bar indication, that only shows the carbon-extension with the root folder hidden:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/172399/28363680-b7960288-6c81-11e7-83d9-0804d32cb950.png)

At this point I was confused. I would have expected that this new workspace also includes carbon-core, since I wanted to add folder to carbon-core. In addition, since the root folder is hidden the only differentiation to an open folder is the different color in the status bar. 

I suggest that the info box wording is changed to:
"Do you want to create a new workspace _for the open folder_"
And the new workspace is then seeded with the currently opened folder.

Reported by smoke test - plus button is not clickable.

data.title: Navigate to previous/ next SCM edit in a file

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Any
- OS Version: Any

Feature Proposal
In JetBrains IDEs such as PyCharm, one can press Ctrl+Atl+Shift+Up Arrow to navigate to the last SCM edit (even for a saved file) and Ctrl+Atl+Shift+Down Arrow to navigate to the next such edit. This is very handy in navigating to & further editing existing edits in a file.

data.title: 'Add Folder to Workspace' does nothing in an empty window
data.body:
Testing #30722 

- File>New Window
- Workspaces>Add Folder
-> nothing happens

data.title: debug continues to use launch.json from removed folder
data.body:
Testing #30722:

- workspace with three folders: the first with launch config, two without
- go to debug viewlet and open launch config drop down
   -> it should show the launch configs
- remove the folder with the launch configs from workspace
- go to debug viewlet and open launch config drop down
   -> it correctly show "No configuration"
- press on the gear item
   -> launch.json from the removed folder is opened

data.title: Workspaces - cannot distinguish different untitled workspaces
data.body: There should be a way to distinguish untitled workspaces, by numbering them, e.g. "Untitled Workspace 1".

data.title: Change the behavior of file extension associations
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:08:57.197Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
vscode-dash|dee|1.7.0
tslint|eg2|0.16.0
vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.2.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install Visual Studio Code
2. Click on any previously unassigned extension
3. Visual Studio Code will be opened instead of the previous app or nothing

I tried out Visual Studio Code and it is working fine but we are still in getting know each other phase. 

Unfortunately Visual Studio Code aggressively assigned itself to all the extensions it knows and that feels very intrusive. I tried to un-assign the associations with [RCDefaultApp](http://www.rubicode.com/Software/RCDefaultApp/) without any luck.

Could you please somehow change the behavior or not assign anything by default? Thanks!

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Is there a way to delete an untitled workspace?
data.body:
Testing #30722

I've created several untitled workspaces. How do I get rid of them?

data.title: Pressing tab doesn't move to the desired position anymore after upgrading from 1.13.1
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: `1.14.1`
- OS Version: `OS X EI Capitan 10.11.3`

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I've some code in a C# file, create one **new `empty` line** in the middle of the code which has already a few indents, so the cursor can only be placed at the most-left position,  like the the Line 52 in the picture:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19678455/28362699-77de3f16-6cd1-11e7-977f-460461679dca.png)

2. Now press the <kbd>Tab</kbd>, it moves only **one** tab distance in this case which is annoying:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19678455/28362836-26971a96-6cd2-11e7-8428-fc378adb6f2c.png)
But with the previous version `1.13.1`, the same action will moves **three** tab distance as desired as shown below:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19678455/28362994-c1de4916-6cd2-11e7-98de-f3a5863616fc.png)

data.title: Silly dialog when removing a folder from a workspace
data.body:
Testing #30722:

On removing the first folder from my workspace I get this warning:

![2017-07-19_12-30-11](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1898161/28362804-331c5514-6c7e-11e7-8799-b770badb7f7f.png)

"added or removed" sounds strange since VS Code should know exactly what I did (and I don't think that this alert is even used in the "Add" case).

Either use the correct verb or call it "change".

In addition, the second sentence is not really adding anything new (and there is not even a "restart" button).

data.title: Show workspace name in the title bar (windows)
data.body:
Testing #30722

I've a workspace  called 'npm-vscode':
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/172399/28362827-4b8011b8-6c7e-11e7-88a9-eeba327b67c1.png)

When I open this workspace then the window title shows:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/172399/28362844-5a37848e-6c7e-11e7-8848-ed182450c8aa.png)

I would have expected that the workspace title 'npm-vscode' shows up somewhere in the title bar.

data.title: Make sure that commands around "workspaces" are functional in single- and multi-folder workspaces
data.body:
Refs: #30722

Since we now have a new meaning for Workspace imho we should go through our old uses of workspace in the ui and debate if we should use folder somewhere instead.
Optimally all these actions would update to our new concept of workspace and execute in that context

![screen shot 2017-07-19 at 12 23 12](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926584/28362591-37032ae6-6c7d-11e7-8b81-19fe43e24dc5.png)

data.title: Error when adding a non-existing folder to the *.code-workspace file
data.body:
Testing #30722:

while I had a workspace open, I've edited the underlying *.code-workspace file in another VS Code window and added a path for a non-existing folder. 
I was impressed that the original VS Code workspace picked up the change and immediately showed the folder in the explorer. However clicking on the folder resulted in this error (for obvious reasons):

![2017-07-19_12-16-42](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1898161/28362399-90a93938-6c7c-11e7-8f8d-f32da0b8f36d.png)
 
Fixing the problem by creating the missing folder outside of VS Code seemed to fix the problem for VS Code too (since selecting the folder no longer showed an error).
However, trying to create a file in that folder had no effect and did not produce an error (even in chrome dev tools).

After a window reload I was able to create a file.

data.title: Wokspace folder was removed requires restart -> cancel leaves in strange state
data.body:
Refs: #30722

1. Remove the first root folder
2. Get the Ben vacation dialog -> say cancel
3. The folder still gets removed and me as the user I am puzzled why was the reload even needed.

Expected -> if I press cancel the folder does not get removed

data.title: Why use brackets in workspace title
data.body:
Refs: #30722

Imho brackets look ugly (especially after 1 or 2 words) and this should just be TEST WORKSPACE. Or an alternative WORKSPACE: TEST

![screen shot 2017-07-19 at 12 14 35](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926584/28362222-e7e6cd6a-6c7b-11e7-891c-518f8531e7e3.png)

data.title: Allow to open *.code-workspace file as text file
data.body:
Testing #30722:

just a nit...

Since I was curious how my test.code-workspace file looks like, I tried to open it in VS Code. But this had no effect because VS Code tries to open it as a workspace and that workspace was already open.

data.title: Do not use special color for multi root workspace
data.body:
Refs: #30722

I understand you added a new color to the status bar to make it more distinugshable than the usual experience. Here are my arguments why it should not have a special color:

* We already have indication in the explorer that there are mutliple roots and that the title is different
* The new color is brand new and we do not use it anywhere else, unlike the light blue which goes nicely with the tree selection, some buttons and so on...
* The new color will break exisiting themes and will force them to adpot, in the meantime it will look ugly
* The regular user does not care if he is in a mutli root vs single root. The color difference in no root vs multi root is needed since in no-root we are lacking functionality. While in this situation that is not the case

data.title: Git: "Discard Changes" dialog button defaults are flipped

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
* do some changes
* undo from the git viewlet

macOS: you can hit enter and the changes get discarded
Linux: the cancel button is selected by default so hitting enter means to cancel

It should be consistent across OS imho.

data.title: Unite all the open menu items
data.body:
Refs: #30722

Currently we have Open File, Open Folder, Workspaces > Open Worksace
Can't we just have one Open which if the user chooses a file opens a file, same for folder and workspace.

This seems more natural and easier to use and it seems to be what sublime is doing

![screen shot 2017-07-19 at 12 06 13](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926584/28361921-bbf6c31e-6c7a-11e7-82ce-921bbe8790cb.png)

data.title: Explorer background menu looks a bit silly
data.body:
testing #30722:

The poor explorer background menu is very tiny now (and doesn't look like a menu any more):

![2017-07-19_11-58-13](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1898161/28361637-bb9829ea-6c79-11e7-855d-59e4a48169ef.png)

Some ideas for useful actions that could be added:
- Save Workspace
- Save Workspace as
- Rename Workspace
- Find in Workspace
- New Folder

data.title: Opening *.code-workspace file with non-existing paths leaves workspace in bad state
data.body:
testing #30722:

I tried to use a *.code-workspace file from macOS on linux. Since the paths are invalid, I got this error:
![2017-07-19_11-27-19](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1898161/28360595-3b7fb9e2-6c76-11e7-8ab0-caa734729935.png)

After dismissing the error the workspace showed up like this: 
![2017-07-19_11-35-40](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1898161/28360656-6786a7b2-6c76-11e7-97d1-b78e5750cf3b.png)

But no files showed up in the two folders and trying to create a new file resulted in this error:
![2017-07-19_11-37-32](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1898161/28360733-a9969efa-6c76-11e7-9765-a7d38835a50b.png)

data.title: Multiple selection editing does not always work
data.body:
In some cases, it seems that I cannot edit multiple selected items (only the first one is edited). 

- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: 10.12.5

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Below there is a GIF with that behaviour:
(as you can see, both selection and info in the status bar, there are two items multiple selected - `currentType` and `places`,  yet edited is the only first instance of it. `currentItem` on the other hand is properly edited in two places.



![aaa](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10253750/28360104-c230f67e-6c74-11e7-86cd-3262ad4b786c.gif)

I didn't stumble upon this behaviour in other than `javascript` type of files (probably, because I rarely use them).

Please tell me how can I help you further with that issue (some debugging in the console, etc. ?)
(opinion about visible code quality always welcome :wink: )
